awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Handling a Trillion Unfixable Flaws on Billions of Internet-of-Things
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet-of-Things (IoT) has quickly moved from concept to reality, with estimates that the number of deployed IoT devices will rise to 25 billion in 2020. However, studies show that many IoT devices have serious security vulnerabilities.  Moreover, the limitations of IoT devices and scale of networks of IoT devices often make traditional IT security approaches impractical.  This project takes a first-principles approach to rethinking network security and address these concerns for IoT networks: (1) scalable alternatives to simple perimeter defenses; (2) new methods to manage security in deployed networks of IoT devices; and (3) new security policies with sufficient generality to administer IoT devices and networks in many diverse use-cases. 

By providing a principled architecture to secure IoT deployments, the project will help realize the full potential societal benefits of IoT. The project will result in the development of novel open-source tools, modeling abstractions, algorithms, and prototype implementations that will reduce the time to deploy novel IoT security solutions, and make the results of the project available to the community.  The project's PIs will engage in educational and outreach activities to train the next generation talent for the emerging area of IoT. In particular, the PIs plan to integrate  the interdisciplinary research ideas into courses spanning security, networking, systems and cyber-physical systems. The project will also actively encourage participation from underrepresented groups. Finally, the tools  and measurements generated by this project will inform and accelerate the industry transition to pervasive IoT deployments that are safe and secure.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet-of-Things (IoT) has quickly moved from hype to reality with close to 5 billion IoT devices deployed in 2015 and expectations that this count will rise quickly. Like other disruptive technologies, IoT holds the potential for large-scale societal impact by transforming many industries and our daily lives. 

Unfortunately, significant security risk accompanies the rise of IoT. IoT vendors typically prioritize cost and functionality over security. Thus, vulnerable devices embedded inside networks become attractive attack targets that can compromise the security of our critical infrastructures and users’ privacy. These threats are not hypothetical and several attacks have already been reported; e.g., IoT devices were used to launch DDoS or spam traffic, smart meters were hacked to lower utility bills, and handheld scanners were compromised and used as entry points.

Traditional security solutions that are prevalent in the IT ecosystem (e.g., antivirus and patches) are fundamentally at odds with the realities of the IoT ecosystem (e.g., poor vendor security practices, and constrained hardware). This project took the stance that the network will need to play an even more critical role in securing IoT deployments compared to the traditional IT ecosystem. In this setting,  this project developed a principled set of algorithms, systems, and  open-source tools for securing IoT deployments at the network layer. 

More concretely, the research focused on the following key thrusts and outcomes:

  • Novel capabilities for retrofitting “bolt on” security solutions for insecure IoT devices including software-defined  trustworthy network gateways [Jetfire, HotEdge 2020], refactoring device code [Capture, USENIX 2022];

  • Novel AI/ML solutions for IoT security including the development of novel context-aware federated learning solutions [LofTI,  IoTDI 2020], an extensible stack for developing novel ML-for-IoT solutions [Lumen, Conext 2022], and novel behavioral anomaly detection algorithms [RADAR, CMU TechReport];

  • Novel user-focused capabilities including a food nutrition label inspired IoT Privacy and Security label [IEEE S&P 2020], protecting users from unintended device actions [ICCPS 2021], and helping users discover  unwanted IoT devices [ Lumos, USENIX 2022]] 

  • Novel domain-specific security analysis for specific IoT domains [Canvas, USENIX 2019; Cannon, IEEE S&P 2021].

The project also had a substantial industry, academic, and policy outreach component, through presentations at numerous workshops, industry, and government policy engagements. The project also led to the development of new curriculum material for classes at CMU, multiple collaborative publications at leading security and systems conferences, and the mentoring of multiple graduate students. 


 


Last Modified: 02/07/2023
Modified by: Vyas Sekar
